rsbNotes.title: Josh 5:13–12:24
rsbNotes.text: 5:13–12:24 The second major section of the book tells how the Israelites conquered Canaan. The shocking violence and terrible destruction in these chapters trouble many readers. Yet the text seems to ring with praise to God. This is so because the destruction is the true and just judgment of God on sinners (Gen. 15:16; cf. Lev. 18:24–27; Deut. 9:4, 5), through which He fulfilled His gracious promises to Israel (note the connection between salvation and judgment in Ex. 14:13, 14 and Rev. 19:1, 2). These accounts of destruction, no less than anything else in the book, testify to God’s faithfulness to His promises (cf. the curse in the promise in Gen. 12:3) and prefigure His final judgment on those who reject His grace (Matt. 25:46; Heb. 9:27; 10:26–31).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:3
rsbNotes.text:
9:3 Gibeon. The action of the people of Gibeon (eight miles north of Jerusalem) is in contrast to the general pattern throughout Canaan (vv. 1, 2).

heard. The effect of the news of God’s powerful faithfulness to His promises is an important theme in the account of the conquest (2:10, 11; 5:1; 9:1, 9; 10:1; 11:1; cf. 7:9). For the Canaanites this news was terrifying, for it meant that the God of heaven and earth (2:11) would destroy them (5:13–12:24 note).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:4
rsbNotes.text: 9:4 acted with cunning. This deception will bring a curse on the Gibeonites (v. 23) and is a contrast to Rahab’s action towards the representatives of Israel in ch. 2.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:6
rsbNotes.text:
9:6 We have come from a distant country. The Gibeonites pretend that they live outside Israel’s potential zone of interest. The Israelites were prepared to make a treaty with them because of the provisions of Deut. 20:10–18.

covenant. A covenant is a treaty relationship. This covenant would commit Israel to spare the Gibeonites.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:7
rsbNotes.text: 9:7 Hivites. This ethnic group, to which the Gibeonites belonged, was one of those God had promised to drive out of Canaan (3:10).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:9
rsbNotes.text:
9:9 name. See note 7:9.

heard. See note on v. 3.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:10
rsbNotes.text:
9:10 all that he did. The news the Gibeonites had heard is the same as that confessed by Rahab (2:10 note). Their reaction was quite different from hers.

Amorites. See note 2:10.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:14
rsbNotes.text: 9:14 did not ask counsel from the Lord. How they should have sought counsel is not specified, but as in 5:6, Israel’s failure is a failure to obey God.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:15
rsbNotes.text: 9:15 made peace. The sense is explained by the following phrase “to let them live.”

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:16–17
rsbNotes.text: 9:16, 17 three days . . . the third day. If v. 16 anticipates the result of v. 17, then the three days in each verse may be the same. From Gilgal to Gibeon is about nineteen miles.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:18
rsbNotes.text: 9:18 murmured. Grumbling (against Moses, Aaron, and ultimately the Lord) was a common activity of Israel in the desert (Ex. 15:24; 16:2, 7–9; 17:3; Num. 14:2, 27, 36).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:20
rsbNotes.text: 9:20 wrath. See 7:11 and note. Contrast this oath, kept scrupulously although based on a Gibeonite lie, and the covenant of ch. 7:11, based on the Lord’s command, but broken.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:21
rsbNotes.text: 9:21 cutters of wood and drawers of water. That is, household slaves.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:23
rsbNotes.text:
9:23 house. The tabernacle is called a house in 1 Sam. 1:7. At the time of Solomon the tabernacle was at Gibeon (2 Chr. 1:3, 5).

my God. The danger posed by Canaanites remaining in the land was that they would turn Israel from following the Lord to serve other gods (Deut. 7:4). The implication of this curse is that the Gibeonites would serve in the house of Israel’s God without being counted as members of His people. The rituals and sacrifices of the tabernacle required supplies of wood and water.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:24
rsbNotes.text: 9:24 feared greatly. See note 2:9.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 9:27
rsbNotes.text:
9:27 the place that he should choose. See Deut. 12; cf. Ex. 20:24.

to this day. See note 4:9.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10
rsbNotes.text: 10:1–43 The hostility anticipated in 9:1, 2 begins to emerge; in ch. 10 the hostile nations to the south are overthrown by remarkable divine intervention. The scheming of the five kings (v. 4) and their destruction (v. 26, 40–42) is like what is described in Ps. 2 (9:1, 2 note), and demonstrates the great power of God to fulfill His promises. This is the kind of battle described in Deut. 20, not ultimately fought by Israel but by God (v. 14 and Deut. 20:4).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:1
rsbNotes.text:
10:1 Adoni-zedek. His name means “my Lord is righteous.” Compare the name of Melchizedek, who was king in Salem (or Jerusalem); see Gen. 14:18 note.

Jerusalem. This is the first time this form of the city’s name occurs in the Bible; in Gen. 14:18 it is referred to as “Salem.”

destruction. See notes 6:17, 18.

peace. See 9:15.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:2
rsbNotes.text:
10:2 feared. See note 2:9.

a great city, like one of the royal cities. Gibeon did not have a king (9:11) but was as important as the Canaanite city-states with kings.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:3
rsbNotes.text: 10:3 Hoham . . . Debir. These were the kings of five southern Canaanite cities.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:5
rsbNotes.text: 10:5 Amorites. See note 2:10.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:6
rsbNotes.text: 10:6 save us and help us. The treaty relationship between Gibeon and Israel (9:15) allowed Gibeon to appeal for help from Israel, the stronger of the treaty partners. This aspect of a human covenant illustrates an aspect of the covenant between God and Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:8
rsbNotes.text: 10:8 Do not fear . . . I have given them. The particular actions in this chapter take place under the promises of God introduced in ch. 1. See 1:2, 3, 5–9; 8:1 and notes.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:9
rsbNotes.text: 10:9 all night. Gilgal was at the bottom of the Jordan Valley and Gibeon was on top of a mountain twenty miles to the west.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:10
rsbNotes.text: 10:10 threw them into a panic. The same expression is often used in descriptions of battles where the Lord is the Divine Warrior (2:9 note; Ex. 14:24; 23:27; Judg. 4:15; 1 Sam. 7:10; 2 Sam. 22:15; cf. Jer. 51:34).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:11
rsbNotes.text: 10:11 more who died because of the hailstones. This emphasizes that the victory was a gift to Israel. Experiences like this illuminate the use of storm phenomena in poetic descriptions of God’s judgment (Ps. 18:7–16; Is. 30:30).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:12
rsbNotes.text:
10:12 in the day. This account may be a flashback; the chronological order of events is hard to discern.

“Sun . . . moon.” These rhetorical words addressed to the sun and moon are in reality a prayer to the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:13
rsbNotes.text:
10:13 the sun stood still. The words describe what happened in everyday language that does not explain the nature of the miracle.

the Book of Jashar. A literary work now lost, possibly a celebration of the lives of Israelite heroes (2 Sam. 1:18). The quotation from the Book of Jashar may extend as far as the end of v. 15. The biblical writers often use written sources (Luke 1:1–4).

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:14
rsbNotes.text: 10:14 the Lord fought for Israel. See Deut. 20, especially v. 4; cf. Ex. 14:14.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:16–27
rsbNotes.text: 10:16–27 The narrative returns to the events of v. 10 to finish the story of the five kings introduced in v. 5.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:19
rsbNotes.text: 10:19 the Lord . . . has given. The action of God, in terms of His promise, still dominates the account. See vv. 8, 10, 14.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:21
rsbNotes.text: 10:21 Not a man moved his tongue. Not even a word, let alone a weapon, could be raised against God’s army.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:24
rsbNotes.text: 10:24 your feet on the necks. This is a vivid, symbolic ritual of victory. Defeated enemies are often said to be “under the feet” of the victor (1 Kin. 5:3; Ps. 110:1; 1 Cor. 15:25), and Egyptian royal footstools depict the Pharaoh’s feet on his enemies’ necks.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:26
rsbNotes.text: 10:26 hanged them on five trees. See note 8:29.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:27
rsbNotes.text: 10:27 to this very day. See note 4:9.

rsbNotes.title: Josh 10:28–39
rsbNotes.text: 10:28–39 These verses are a summary account of victories over cities in southern Canaan. The account emphasizes the complete destruction of the towns according to the judgment of God (vv. 28–39; 6:17, 18 and notes). Another emphasis is the unity of Israel (1:12–15) under Joshua’s leadership (1:1–9).
